content.webTitle: What the tourist board doesn't tell you

fields.headline: What the tourist board doesn't tell you
fields.bodyText: If you're heading for Turkey this summer, pack some euros (including a few euro coins) along with your sun cream and bikini. The necessity of this hit us within minutes of arriving in Antalya airport. The machines dispensing trolleys took euro coins only - forget the Turkish lira, never mind the pound. As the two-week holiday progressed, we realised that the euro has been adopted as a parallel currency to the inflation-stricken lira. This is not only a reflection of the fact that Turkey is aiming for membership of the EU. With the lira fluctuating substantially on an almost daily basis, the euro is a much safer currency for tour operators to quote local excursions in - even if you pay lira for them in the end. You may also get a better exchange rate on euros than on sterling. You may also find, as we did, that the hotel you're staying at suddenly won't accept credit cards. So bring a debit card, which you can use in the ubiquitous cash machines, and make sure you have enough in your account back home, or a good overdraft, to cover your holiday expenditures.
